elements.content: Three novel heterobimetallic coordination polymers, {Na2[Cd(odpa)(H2O)]} n (1), {Na2[Zn(odpa)(H2O)]} n (2), and {Na2[Cd3(odpa)2(H2O)5]·1.5H2O} n (3) (H4odpa = 4,4′-oxydiphthalic acid), have been prepared under solvothermal conditions and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compounds 1 and 2 are unprecedented 2D bilayer anion networks containing 26- and 24- membered channels made of Cd/Zn polyhedra linked by (odpa)4− ligand, while a novel 2D Na−O network is inserted subtly in the bilayer networks. Compound 3 presents a three-dimensional coordination polymer based on both tetranuclear and hexanuclear heterobimetallic clusters containing one-dimensional hydrophilic channels, where guest water molecules reside. Furthermore, these heterobimetallic clusters connected to each other to build a Cd−Na polyhedral network existing in a 3D anion framework. Compounds 1−3 are all heterobimetallic Cd/Zn−Na compounds containing polymeric anions, which have not been reported in all coordination polymers of (odpa)4− ligand. In 1−3, central CdII/ZnII ions and (odpa)4− ligand display completely different coordination modes and conformations. In addition, the thermal stabilities and photoluminescence properties were also studied.

elements.content: The crystal engineering of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) has grown into a subject that attracts intense attention because controlling molecular organization in the solid state can lead to materials with novel structure and promising properties. These MOFs can be rapidly and efficiently synthesized from relatively simple subunits, where the kind of metal ions, geometry, and number of coordination sites provided by organic ligands are all important parameters for directing the self-assembly processes. The rational design and reasonable use of the characteristic ligand is very important in the construction of desired MOFs. Since a carboxylate group can bridge metal ions to give rise to a wide variety of polynuclear complexes ranging from discrete entities to three-dimensional systems, many polycarboxylate ligands, such as 1,2- benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate, have been extensively employed in the preparation of such metal−organic complexes in possession of multidimensional networks and interesting properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The crystal engineering of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has grown into a subject that attracts intense attention because controlling molecular organization in the solid state can lead to materials with novel structure and promising properties. These MOFs can be rapidly and efficiently synthesized from relatively simple subunits, where the kind of metal ions, geometry, and number of coordination sites provided by organic ligands are all important parameters for directing the self-assembly processes. The rational design and reasonable use of the characteristic ligand is very important in the construction of desired MOFs. Since a carboxylate group can bridge metal ions to give rise to a wide variety of polynuclear complexes ranging from discrete entities to three-dimensional systems, many polycarboxylate ligands, such as 1,2- benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate, have been extensively employed in the preparation of such metal-organic complexes in possession of multidimensional networks and interesting properties.

elements.content: As a member of polycarboxylate ligands, 4,4′-oxydiphthalic acid (H4odpa) contains nine potential metal binding sites, which can yield the formation of a MOF through multiple bonding interactions, adopt different conformations and coordination modes (Scheme ), and provide abundant structural motifs. Therefore, the (odpa)4− ligand may be an excellent candidate for the construction of multidimensional coordination polymers, especially 3D open or porous frameworks. However, coordination polymers constructed from the (odpa)4− ligand have rarely been reported. With the aim of understanding the coordination chemistry of this versatile ligand and preparing new materials with interesting structural topologies and excellent physical properties, we have recently engaged in the research of coordination polymers based on 4,4′-oxydiphthalic acid (H4odpa). We have successfully obtained some d10 metal−organic coordination polymers from the (odpa)4− ligand. However, the change in metal centers may produce strikingly different structures. Especially, heterometal atoms with their high and variable coordination numbers and flexible coordination environments provide unique opportunities for discovery of unusual network topologies. But the reported coordination polymers constructed from the (odpa)4− ligand are all based on individual metal atoms; those constructed by two different metal atoms have not been reported. Therefore, the construction of heterometallic odpa complexes is still a great challenge for synthetic chemists, and further research is necessary to enrich and develop this field.

elements.clean_text: 1  The Coordination Modes of (odpa)4- in 1-3

elements.content: In order to synthesize novel heterometallic odpa coordination polymers, the reactions of d10 metal salts with (odpa)4− ligand were carried out in hydrothermal conditions. Luckily, we obtained three novel heterobimetallic coordination polymers, {Na2[Cd(odpa)(H2O)]} n (1), {Na2[Zn(odpa)(H2O)]} n (2), and {Na2[Cd3(odpa)2(H2O)5]·1.5H2O} n (3). Compounds 1−3 are all constructed from polymeric d10 metal and alkaline metal ions, while illustrating different structures. In this paper, we report their synthesis, characterization, crystal structures, and photoluminescence.

Compounds 1-3 are all constructed from polymeric d10 metal and alkaline metal ions, while illustrating different structures. In this paper, we report their synthesis, characterization, crystal structures, and photoluminescence.

elements.content: 4,4′-Oxydiphthalic anhydride was purchased from Alfa Aesar. The other chemicals and reagents were used as received from commercial sources without further purification. All reactions were carried out under hydrothermal conditions. Elemental analyses (C, H) were determined with an Elementar Vario EL III elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a Bruker EQUINOX55 spectrophotometer in the 4000−400 cm−1 region. Fluorescence spectra were performed on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a Universal V2.6 DTA Instruments.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

4,4'-Oxydiphthalic anhydride was purchased from Alfa Aesar. The other chemicals and reagents were used as received from commercial sources without further purification. All reactions were carried out under hydrothermal conditions. Elemental analyses (C, H) were determined with an Elementar Vario EL III elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a Bruker EQUINOX55 spectrophotometer in the 4000-400 cm-1 region. Fluorescence spectra were performed on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a Universal V2.6 DTA Instruments.

elements.content: A mixture of CdCO3 (34.4 mg, 0.2 mmol), 4,4′-oxydiphthalic anhydride (31.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bpy) (15.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), and CH3COONa (41.0 mg, 0.5 mmol) in ethanol (5 mL) and water (5 mL) was stirred for 30 min in air, then sealed in a 15 mL Telfon-lined stainless steel container, which was heated to 160 °C for 96 h, then cooled to 100 °C at a rate of 5 °C/h and kept at 100 °C for 10 h. After cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h, colorless crystals were obtained, 49.8 mg, 96% yield based on (odpa)4−. Anal. Calcd for C16H8CdNa2O10 (518.60): C, 37.05; H, 1.55. Found: C, 37.10; H, 1.58. IR (cm−1): 3419 (m), 2360 (w), 1564 (s), 1413 (s), 1261 (m), 1222 (s), 1148 (w), 1073 (w), 960 (w), 859 (m), 806 (m), 724 (w), 630 (w).

elements.content: Intensity data were collected on a Bruker Smart APEX II CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Empirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares based on F 2 using SHELXTL-97 program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms of organic ligands were generated geometrically. Crystal data and structural refinement parameters for 1−3 are summarized in Table and selected bond distances and bond angles are listed in Table S1 (). Crystallographic data for the structural analyses have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, CCDC Nos. 676941−676943 for 1−3. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.can.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, U.K., fax (+44) 1223−336033, or deposit @ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

X-ray Crystallography

Intensity data were collected on a Bruker Smart APEX II CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Empirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares based on F 2 using SHELXTL-97 program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms of organic ligands were generated geometrically. Crystal data and structural refinement parameters for 1-3 are summarized in Table  and selected bond distances and bond angles are listed in Table S1 (). Crystallographic data for the structural analyses have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, CCDC Nos. 676941-676943 for 1-3. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.can.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, U.K., fax (+44) 1223-336033, or deposit @ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

Hydro(solvo)thermal synthesis is a powerful method for preparation of coordination polymers due to their low solubility in common solvents. Compounds 1 and 2 were synthesized using (odpa)4− (from 4,4′-oxydiphthalic anhydride) and 4,4′-bpy ligands under the same hydrothermal reaction conditions but with different metal salts. As result, similar 2-D bilayer networks of 1 and 2 were obtained, but the (odpa)4− ligand shows different coordination modes, which revealed that the metal salt has certain influence on the syntheses of the compounds. We tried to extend our study to other compounds based on (odpa)4− ligands. Compound 3 was synthesized using the same reaction mixture as 1 under different hydrothermal synthesis conditions. Compound 1 forms two-dimensional (2D) bilayer networks, while 3 shows a three-dimensional (3D) framework, suggesting that the hydrothermal synthesis conditions have critical impact on the structure. A phase equilibrium of a multicomponent system is formed at certain temperature and pressure. Many metastable phases exist at hydrothermal conditions and some metastable components may be crystallized. In our experiment, compound 3 was crystallized from the same reaction mixture as 1 under different hydrothermal conditions. It is noteworthy that 4,4′-bpy does not appear in 1−3. Similar situations also occurred in other systems. To examine the effect of 4,4′-bpy, direct reactions of metal salts (ZnII or CdII) with (odpa)4− ligand under the same hydrothermal conditions were carried out. The products are white precipitates, which are different from compounds 1−3, confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction. Furthermore, in our other studies based on (odpa)4− ligand, we used other second ligands, such as 2,2′-bipyridine (2,2′-bpy), 1,10-phenanthroline (phen), and 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene (dpe) ligands instead of 4,4′-bpy, and obtained the metal complexes with the second ligand. The aforementioned phenomena did not happen. We propose that the 4,4′-bpy ligand may play an important role as template, base, or both in the formation of 1−3.

Results and Discussion

Syntheses

Hydro(solvo)thermal synthesis is a powerful method for preparation of coordination polymers due to their low solubility in common solvents. Compounds 1 and 2 were synthesized using (odpa)4- (from 4,4'-oxydiphthalic anhydride) and 4,4'-bpy ligands under the same hydrothermal reaction conditions but with different metal salts. As result, similar 2-D bilayer networks of 1 and 2 were obtained, but the (odpa)4- ligand shows different coordination modes, which revealed that the metal salt has certain influence on the syntheses of the compounds. We tried to extend our study to other compounds based on (odpa)4- ligands. Compound 3 was synthesized using the same reaction mixture as 1 under different hydrothermal synthesis conditions. Compound 1 forms two-dimensional (2D) bilayer networks, while 3 shows a three-dimensional (3D) framework, suggesting that the hydrothermal synthesis conditions have critical impact on the structure. A phase equilibrium of a multicomponent system is formed at certain temperature and pressure. Many metastable phases exist at hydrothermal conditions and some metastable components may be crystallized. In our experiment, compound 3 was crystallized from the same reaction mixture as 1 under different hydrothermal conditions. It is noteworthy that 4,4'-bpy does not appear in 1-3. Similar situations also occurred in other systems. To examine the effect of 4,4'-bpy, direct reactions of metal salts (ZnII or CdII) with (odpa)4- ligand under the same hydrothermal conditions were carried out. The products are white precipitates, which are different from compounds 1-3, confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction. Furthermore, in our other studies based on (odpa)4- ligand, we used other second ligands, such as 2,2'-bipyridine (2,2'-bpy), 1,10-phenanthroline (phen), and 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene (dpe) ligands instead of 4,4'-bpy, and obtained the metal complexes with the second ligand. The aforementioned phenomena did not happen. We propose that the 4,4'-bpy ligand may play an important role as template, base, or both in the formation of 1-3.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 is a 2D bilayer coordination polymer containing dimeric Cd2 units and a novel Na−O network inserted in the structure. The asymmetric unit of 1 has one cadmium(II) atom and two crystallographically independent sodium atoms, one (odpa)4− anion, and one coordinated water molecule (Figure a). The Cd−O bond lengths are in the range of 2.256(2)−2.780(2) Å, in good agreement with previous strudies. The distance of 2.780(2) Å is a little long, which is a nonnegligible interaction. Thus, the CdII atom can be regarded as seven-coordinated. Each CdII atom is coordinated by seven oxygen atoms belonging to five different carboxylate groups of five separated (odpa)4− ligands. The coordination geometry of the Cd1 center can be described as a distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry. Five atoms (O1, O2, O4A, O6A, and O7A) comprise the equatorial plane, while another two atoms (O3A and O8A) occupy the axial positions. The Na1 atom is six-coordinated, tightly bonded by five oxygen atoms from five different carboxylate groups of three (odpa)4− ligands and one oxygen atom from one water molecule to complete a slightly distorted trigonal prism geometry with O7, O8, and O10 atoms composing one triangular plane and O2B, O2C, and O3B atoms composing the other plane, which is relatively scarce compared with the common octahedral coordination. The Na1−O bond distances are in the range of 2.320(2)−2.583(3) Å. The Na2 center is ligated by one oxygen atom from one water molecule and four oxygen atoms from four different carboxylate groups of three (odpa)4− ligands to complete a distorted trigonal-bipyramidal geometry with the three atoms (O4B, O7, and O9B) in the equatorial plane and two oxygen atom (O9A and O10) in the axial positions. A five-coordinate Na atom is rare in the complexes. The Na2−O bond distances range from 2.304(3) to 2.710(3) Å, whereas the O−Na−O angles are in the range from 69.03(9)° to 164.43(11)°, responsible for the distorted triangular prism. The shortest distances between the metal centers within the inorganic plane are 4.882 (Cd···Cd), 3.702 (Na1···Na1), 3.647 (Na2···Na2), and 3.828 Å (Na1···Na2).

elements.content: On the basis of the connection modes, each pair of CdII centers is bridged by a pair of carboxylate groups from two different (odpa)4− ligands to form a Cd2O4C2 dimeric unit containing a type of pore with size of ca. 7.297 Å × 6.549 Å based on the distances of C2···C2 and Cd1···Cd1. The dimeric Cd2 units are linked by eight carboxylate groups of four (odpa)4− ligands generating a 1D [Cd2(odpa)2] n 4n− double-chain running along the a axis (Figure b), thus forming a novel {Cd2O6C18} 26-membered ring containing a type of pore with size of ca. 10.60 Å × 12.01 Å based on the distances of Cd1···Cd1 and O5···O5. Interestingly, the adjacent 1D double chains are parallel to each other and further linked by carboxylate groups of (odpa)4− ligands to form an infinite anion bilayer running along the c axis (Figure c).

elements.content: When CdII ion is replaced by ZnII ion, a d10 metal ion with smaller radius, analogous 2D double layers are formed in 2 under similar reaction conditions. The coordination environment of ZnII is similar to that of CdII, but the ZnII center is six-coordinated by one pair of chelating oxygen atoms from one (odpa)4− ligand and four oxygen atoms from four carboxylate groups of four different (odpa)4− ligands, which is different from that of the CdII center (seven-coordinated). The ZnII center adopts a distorted octahedron geometry; four oxygen atoms (O4A, O6A, O8, and O9A) comprise the equatorial plane, and another two oxygen atoms (O1A and O7A) occupy the axial positions. The Zn−O bond lengths are in the range of 2.250(7)−2.485(6) Å, which is comparable to other ZnII complexes reported, and the O−Zn−O angles vary from 54.4(2)° to 169.5(2)°. The coordination environments of Na atoms are similar to those of 1, and the Na−O bond lengths and O−Na−O bond angles are comparable to those of 1.

elements.content: Compound 3 features an unusual 3D coordinated polymer based on both tetranuclear and hexanuclear heterobimetallic clusters containing a 1D channel and a 2D Cd−Na polyhedra network inserting in the 3D anion framework. The asymmetric unit of 3 contains three independent CdII ions, two sodium ions, two (odpa)4− anions, and five coordinated water molecules, as well as one and a half lattice water molecules (Figure a). The Cd1 is seven-coordinated with seven oxygen atoms belonging to five different carboxylate groups from four individual (odpa)4− ligands, forming a slightly distorted monocapped octahedral coordination geometry. The Cd−O bond lengths are in the range of 2.224(9)−2.623(11) Å, in good agreement with previous studies. The Cd2 possesses a slightly distorted octahedron coordination geometry, which comprised four oxygen atoms of three (odpa)4− ligands and two oxygen atoms of two water molecules. The bond distances of Cd2−O and angles of O−Cd2−O lie in the range of 2.243(9)−2.379(11) Å and 54.9(3)−170.1(4)°, respectively. Similar to Cd1, except for the slight difference in bond lengths and angles listed in Table S1 (), Cd3 exhibits a similar distorted monocapped octahedral environment, which is surrounded by six oxygen atoms from four (odpa)4− ligands. The Cd−O bond distances are in the range of 2.201(9)−2.649(12) Å, which is comparable to other cadmium(II) complexes reported. Each Na1 atom is coordinated to three oxygen atoms from two (odpa)4− ligands and four oxygen atoms of aqua ligands, with five oxygen atoms (O2, O3A, O20, O21, and O19A) in the equatorial plane and two oxygen atoms (O18A and O22) in the axial positions resulting in a distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry. The Na2 atom is six-bonded by five oxygen atoms from five different carboxylate groups of four (odpa)4− ligands and one oxygen atom from one coordinated water molecule to complete a slightly distorted octahedral geometry. The Na−O bond lengths are in the range of 2.281(10)−2.897(12) Å, and the O−Na−O angles vary from 64.6(3)° to 169.6(5)°.

elements.content: The architecture of 3D heterobimetallic coordinated polymers based on heterobimetallic clusters is extremely rare. However, such a structure based on tetranuclear clusters and hexanuclear heterobimetallic clusters are observed in 3, shown in Figure b. The centrosymmetric tetranuclear cluster is constructed from two Cd3 atoms, two Na2 atoms, four (odpa)4− ligands, and one-coordinated water molecule. Two longer Cd−Na edges of 3.811 Å and two shorter Cd−Na edges of 3.541 Å construct a parallelogram Cd2Na2 cluster core, angles of Na1−Cd1−Na1 and Cd1−Na1−Cd1 being 110.72° and 69.28°, respectively. The hexanuclear clusters are constructed from four Cd atoms (two Cd1 and two Cd2), two Na1 atoms, six (odpa)4− ligands, and six coordinated water molecules. These hexanuclear clusters are connected through the coordination of carboxylate oxygen atoms of (odpa)4− ligands, forming a 1D chain. Then the adjacent 1D chains are connected to each other with tetranuclear heterometallic clusters to generate a 2D Cd−Na polyhedra layer running along the b-axis (Figure c). The 2D layer is further interconnected by carboxylate groups of (odpa)4− ligands to form a 3D framework containing one-dimensional hydrophilic channels, where guest water molecules reside (Figure d). Such a 3D polymer based on tetranuclear and hexanuclear heterometallic clusters has never been found in all known coordination polymers with (odpa)4− ligand. Furthermore, in 1 and 2, Na1 and Na2 atoms connected with carboxylate groups form an infinite Na−O network situated in the 2D [M(odpa)] n 2n− anion bilayer network. When Na1 and Na2 atoms were deleted, the 2D [M(odpa)] n 2n−anion bilayer network did not collapse. But in 3, Na1 and Na2 atoms connected with carboxylate groups form Na−O polyhedra by sharing vertexes, which connected Cd−O polyhedra with each other to form a 2D Cd−Na polyhedra network situated in the [Cd3(odpa)2(H2O)5] n 2n− anion network. However the 3D structure collapsed without Na1 atoms in 3, which is different from 1 and 2. Obviously, Na1 atoms play an important joint role in 3.

elements.content: By self-assembly from the multifunctional (odpa)4− ligand, we obtained three new compounds. In 1−3, the (odpa)4− ligand shows three different coordination modes and two different conformations (Scheme ). To the best of our knowledge, these coordination modes have not been described before in metal compounds with (odpa)4− ligand.

elements.content: Also deserving attention, four bonding modes have been observed according to the coordination environment of the four carboxylate groups, as shown in Figure S1 (). Each multifunctional (odpa)4− ligand acts as a bridging ligand connecting some CdII/ZnII ions and sodium ions through its four carboxylate groups. The number of coordination sites is 19 bonds to 11 metals (Cd5Na6) of the (odpa)4− in 1, 15 bonds to 11 metals (Zn5Na6) in 2, and 15 bonds to 10 metals (Cd6Na4) in 3. To our knowledge, the number of coordination sites (19 bonds to 11 metals) of the (odpa)4− ligand here is the highest known of polycarboxylate ligands.

elements.content: To study the thermal stabilities of these complexes, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of compounds 1−3 was performed. Compound 1 first lost its coordinated water molecules below 120 °C; the weight loss found of 3.7% was consistent with that calculated (3.5%). After the loss of water molecules, the 2D framework was stable up to 275 °C and then began to decompose upon further heating. The TG curve of 2 shows an initial weight loss of 3.9% below 230 °C corresponding to the removal of coordinated water molecules (calcd 3.8%); then the compound was relatively stable up to 320 °C, followed by two-step weight loss in the range of 320−730 °C. The second weight loss is 54.56% from 320 to 500 °C, and the third step is 10.88% from 500 to 760 °C, both assigned to the decomposition of (odpa)4− ligands (calcd 65.7%; found 65.4%). The TG curve of 3 shows an initial weight loss of 2.4% below 78 °C corresponding to the removal of lattice water molecules (calcd 2.3%). The second weight loss is 8.3% in the temperature range of 78−250 °C corresponding to the removal of coordinated water molecules (calcd 7.6%), followed by a continuously weight loss of 57.4% from 250 to 505 °C (calcd 57.8%). The TGA results of 1−3 show that they are stable below 250 °C, which indicates their good thermal stability (Figure S2, , shows the TG curves for 1−3).
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

To study the thermal stabilities of these complexes, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of compounds 1-3 was performed. Compound 1 first lost its coordinated water molecules below 120 °C; the weight loss found of 3.7% was consistent with that calculated (3.5%). After the loss of water molecules, the 2D framework was stable up to 275 °C and then began to decompose upon further heating. The TG curve of 2 shows an initial weight loss of 3.9% below 230 °C corresponding to the removal of coordinated water molecules (calcd 3.8%); then the compound was relatively stable up to 320 °C, followed by two-step weight loss in the range of 320-730 °C. The second weight loss is 54.56% from 320 to 500 °C, and the third step is 10.88% from 500 to 760 °C, both assigned to the decomposition of (odpa)4- ligands (calcd 65.7%; found 65.4%). The TG curve of 3 shows an initial weight loss of 2.4% below 78 °C corresponding to the removal of lattice water molecules (calcd 2.3%). The second weight loss is 8.3% in the temperature range of 78-250 °C corresponding to the removal of coordinated water molecules (calcd 7.6%), followed by a continuously weight loss of 57.4% from 250 to 505 °C (calcd 57.8%). The TGA results of 1-3 show that they are stable below 250 °C, which indicates their good thermal stability (Figure S2, , shows the TG curves for 1-3).

elements.content: Taking into account the excellent luminescent properties of d10 metal complexes, the luminescence of 1, 3, and 4,4′-oxydiphthalic anhydride were investigated, shown in Figure . Unfortunately, compound 2 exhibits very weak emission. The ligand exhibits one weak emission band at 389 nm upon excitation at 245 nm. Compound 1 exhibits a intense emission peak at ca. 430 nm upon excitation at 245 nm, which means a red shift of ca. 41 nm relative to that of the free ligand (λmax = 389 nm). It is hard to propose a correct mechanistic conclusion for their luminescence based only on emission spectra. According to the literature and by considering the fact that the molecular orbital calculations suggested the photoemission of previously reported cadmium(II) coordination polymers to be mainly LMCT, the emission band of 1 may be tentatively assigned to LMCT. Compound 3 also exhibits an intense emission peak upon excitation at the same excitation condition. The emission peak is located at 396 nm for 3, which is assigned to the intraligand (π−π*) transitions of the ligand. By comparing the emission spectra of 1, 3, and ligand, we can conclude that the enhancement of luminescence in 1 and 3 may be attributed to the ligation of ligand to the metal center, which effectively increases the rigidity and reduces the loss of energy by radiationless decay. These observations indicate that 1 and 3 may be excellent candidates for potential photoactive materials.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

Taking into account the excellent luminescent properties of d10 metal complexes, the luminescence of 1, 3, and 4,4'-oxydiphthalic anhydride were investigated, shown in Figure . Unfortunately, compound 2 exhibits very weak emission. The ligand exhibits one weak emission band at 389 nm upon excitation at 245 nm. Compound 1 exhibits a intense emission peak at ca. 430 nm upon excitation at 245 nm, which means a red shift of ca. 41 nm relative to that of the free ligand (λmax = 389 nm). It is hard to propose a correct mechanistic conclusion for their luminescence based only on emission spectra. According to the literature and by considering the fact that the molecular orbital calculations suggested the photoemission of previously reported cadmium(II) coordination polymers to be mainly LMCT, the emission band of 1 may be tentatively assigned to LMCT. Compound 3 also exhibits an intense emission peak upon excitation at the same excitation condition. The emission peak is located at 396 nm for 3, which is assigned to the intraligand (π-π*) transitions of the ligand. By comparing the emission spectra of 1, 3, and ligand, we can conclude that the enhancement of luminescence in 1 and 3 may be attributed to the ligation of ligand to the metal center, which effectively increases the rigidity and reduces the loss of energy by radiationless decay. These observations indicate that 1 and 3 may be excellent candidates for potential photoactive materials.

elements.content: In summary, we have hydrothermally synthesized three novel heterobimetallic opda coordination polymers under hydrothermal conditions. Interestingly, novel 2D Na−O or Cd−Na polymeric networks were inserted in the anion networks. Different structures of compounds 1−3 indicate that the (odpa)4− ligand has the ability to adjust its coordination modes and configuration in different reaction systems. Furthermore, the coordination polymers based on metal cluster provide not only much more diverse structure but also favorable thermal stability. The successful isolation of these solid materials provides the first examples of heterobimetallic coordination polymers with the (odpa)4− ligand. Compounds 1 and 3 display luminescent properties and may be potential candidates for blue luminescent materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have hydrothermally synthesized three novel heterobimetallic opda coordination polymers under hydrothermal conditions. Interestingly, novel 2D Na-O or Cd-Na polymeric networks were inserted in the anion networks. Different structures of compounds 1-3 indicate that the (odpa)4- ligand has the ability to adjust its coordination modes and configuration in different reaction systems. Furthermore, the coordination polymers based on metal cluster provide not only much more diverse structure but also favorable thermal stability. The successful isolation of these solid materials provides the first examples of heterobimetallic coordination polymers with the (odpa)4- ligand. Compounds 1 and 3 display luminescent properties and may be potential candidates for blue luminescent materials.

A mixture of CdCO3 (34.4 mg, 0.2 mmol), 4,4′-oxydiphthalic anhydride (31.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bpy) (15.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), and CH3COONa (41.0 mg, 0.5 mmol) in ethanol (5 mL) and water (5 mL) was stirred for 30 min in air, then sealed in a 15 mL Telfon-lined stainless steel container, which was heated to 160 °C for 96 h, then cooled to 100 °C at a rate of 5 °C/h and kept at 100 °C for 10 h. After cooling to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C/h, colorless crystals were obtained, 49.8 mg, 96% yield based on (odpa)4−. Anal. Calcd for C16H8CdNa2O10 (518.60): C, 37.05; H, 1.55. Found: C, 37.10; H, 1.58. IR (cm−1): 3419 (m), 2360 (w), 1564 (s), 1413 (s), 1261 (m), 1222 (s), 1148 (w), 1073 (w), 960 (w), 859 (m), 806 (m), 724 (w), 630 (w).

cln_elements.content: To study the thermal stabilities of these complexes, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of compounds 1−3 was performed. Compound 1 first lost its coordinated water molecules below 120 °C; the weight loss found of 3.7% was consistent with that calculated (3.5%). After the loss of water molecules, the 2D framework was stable up to 275 °C and then began to decompose upon further heating. The TG curve of 2 shows an initial weight loss of 3.9% below 230 °C corresponding to the removal of coordinated water molecules (calcd 3.8%); then the compound was relatively stable up to 320 °C, followed by two-step weight loss in the range of 320−730 °C. The second weight loss is 54.56% from 320 to 500 °C, and the third step is 10.88% from 500 to 760 °C, both assigned to the decomposition of (odpa)4− ligands (calcd 65.7%; found 65.4%). The TG curve of 3 shows an initial weight loss of 2.4% below 78 °C corresponding to the removal of lattice water molecules (calcd 2.3%). The second weight loss is 8.3% in the temperature range of 78−250 °C corresponding to the removal of coordinated water molecules (calcd 7.6%), followed by a continuously weight loss of 57.4% from 250 to 505 °C (calcd 57.8%). The TGA results of 1−3 show that they are stable below 250 °C, which indicates their good thermal stability (Figure S2, , shows the TG curves for 1−3).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

To study the thermal stabilities of these complexes, thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of compounds 1-3 was performed. Compound 1 first lost its coordinated water molecules below 120 °C; the weight loss found of 3.7% was consistent with that calculated (3.5%). After the loss of water molecules, the 2D framework was stable up to 275 °C and then began to decompose upon further heating. The TG curve of 2 shows an initial weight loss of 3.9% below 230 °C corresponding to the removal of coordinated water molecules (calcd 3.8%); then the compound was relatively stable up to 320 °C, followed by two-step weight loss in the range of 320-730 °C. The second weight loss is 54.56% from 320 to 500 °C, and the third step is 10.88% from 500 to 760 °C, both assigned to the decomposition of (odpa)4- ligands (calcd 65.7%; found 65.4%). The TG curve of 3 shows an initial weight loss of 2.4% below 78 °C corresponding to the removal of lattice water molecules (calcd 2.3%). The second weight loss is 8.3% in the temperature range of 78-250 °C corresponding to the removal of coordinated water molecules (calcd 7.6%), followed by a continuously weight loss of 57.4% from 250 to 505 °C (calcd 57.8%). The TGA results of 1-3 show that they are stable below 250 °C, which indicates their good thermal stability (Figure S2, , shows the TG curves for 1-3).
